hints.content:
Let's start with the simplest graph. This graph shows a property at $2$ for the whole time period:

![Horizontal line at 2](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/bb9bf74ef08319204cd37bdff0f4fa77a5107883.png)

If the graph represented the position of the ball, then the ball would be stationary for the whole time. This would mean that both the speed and acceleration would have to be at $0$ for the whole time too.

If the graph represented the speed of the ball, then, since its value does not change, acceleration would have to be $0$ for the whole time.

Since there is no graphs that is at $0$ for the whole time, this graph must represent acceleration.

Since acceleration is constant, speed changing at a constant rate.

This graph shows a straight line, which means the value is changing at a constant rate. So this graph can represent speed.

![Diagonal line](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/4e8e002138ce7d6afef024a70c07458031750da0.png)

That leaves this graph to represent position:

![Parabola line](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/8558cc64a9281bea47215a16ef60947caf8b31a2.png)

This graph is a curved line, showing that the position of the ball is changing at a non-constant rate.
